segments.text: They kindly take me under their wings once a year.
They send me back to the hitherlands of New Hampshire, supposedly feeling a little better from this fresh mountain air.
What I neglect to tell them is that we actually have fresh mountain air.
It's just that we have to wait for it to rain a little more frequently because we get all that acid stuff from in the Midwest, but it's good to be here.
and I'm really pleased to be here.
So picture this.
I'm on the third floor, Scram, a bookstore, New York City.
And I'm thinking to myself, what a place.
This is the store that's been around in New York forever.
It's the store that's built
Tremendous collections.
It's the store that authors who we revere today, Faulkner, Hemingway, Annis Ninn, have always have walked through those aisles.
I'm talking with Marvin, the bookseller, the book buyer of 30 years for the Strand, and he's installing the great virtues of this store, and I'm just enthralled.
I leave Marvin, and I go downstairs into the bowels
of the Strand, which is really where the experience of the Strand happens.
And I'm walking around, and all of a sudden I hear this voice.
I can't see anybody, but I hear this voice.
It's here.
I know it's here.
I know it's here.
I've got to find it.
It's here.
So I'm now curious.
And I start trying to find the voice and I start chasing it through the aisles and I'm going from travel to a dramatic attack.
And about the fourth aisle I catch up with it and I run around the corner and all of a sudden I literally bump into Nicholas Vansman.
And I said, Nicholas, what are you doing here?
And he kind of
At first, he's trying to be polite, but you know in his eyes he's got this goal, this mission.
He gives me a hello, but he's off in another world.
And I said, what is it?
It's here.
I know it's here.
I've got to find it.
What, what?
And I'm saying, if I can get it for him.
I'm younger.
I can dash up to the second floor, get through the checkout counter, and be lost in a city of 10 million people before he knew what's happened.
And he finally says, it's got to be here.
I says, what, Nicholas?
He says, that unsigned John Dunning novel.
That's good.
I'm out of here.
You see, I'm the non-fiction one.
I have to tell you, it's giving me great pleasure to make that story up.
I started to put it together, I said, I'm not having one of these seen you more.
We did meet at the Strand.
There is a thread of truth to all stories.
And the truth of it is, I did meet Nicholas Baffing last February in the basement of the Strand.

It is true, I was on the third floor talking with Marvin, and I said to Nicholas after we said hello, I said, you know, Nicholas, it would be wonderful to have you and John Dunning on a platform together.
I said, you guys are just great.
I said, I know John, I know you.
I said, you know, you both are opinionated, you've got ideas, you know, something could happen.
And he says, great.
I said,
call John.
Well, John is off on the road, so I write him an email, little did I know, he's on this 10,000 mile book tour from, I think he refers to it as the book tour tour of hell.
And I start emailing him.

So my first email, I kind of try to set it up, and I tell him, you know, Nicholas Batchman really likes your works, he's never had a chance to meet you, he wants to meet you, how about coming to New Hampshire and doing a program?
And I get this short little curse response.
I don't fly.
So I say to myself, all right, let me try again.
So I grovel through a couple more emails.
And John finally writes back to me and says, why don't you guys come out here?
Now, I'm guessing that John's thinking that that's going to finish that story.
But John didn't know that my resources were a little deeper than he might have expected.
And I got through to the committee and to Lois.
and they loved the idea, and now we are here.
And that part is really exciting.
So, why are we here today?
Where's the bar?
Yes, okay, why are we here today?
Well, in a few well-known paraphrased words,
It's the story, stupid.
That's why we're here.
It's the story.
It's the story not just of every book, but the story about every book, about every copy of every book.
It's the story about who wrote it, who owned it, who signed it, who read it, who collected it, how did it get here, why is it different from any other copy or printing?
What's the association?
What's unusual about this copy?
Where did I find it?
What a bargain I got here.
How does it fit into my collection?
These are all the stories we tell when we show our books and talk about our collection.
Well, today we have Nicholas Vassbain, who's written in Gentle Madness, Among the Gently Mad, Patience and Fortitude, in his latest book, Splendors of Letters,
who has done a great service to the book world by collecting stories about book collectors, some of which may have been lost through the ages, were it not for his gift of investigative reporting.
Nicholas writes about the life of the book, and we have John Dunn, who in his
who really doesn't need an introduction.
He writes about the death of the book.
That's not interesting.
He needs no introduction.
You've been reading him since he worked at the Denver Post, his first book, Holland Suggestion, 1972, his Janeway novel, his encyclopedic bedtime book,
on radio shows, in his chapbook, Book Scout, is a personal favorite.
John gives life to the book, expecting that there someday may be apocryphal stories about this event here today.
About these two men, locked, locked, tusk to tusk, in their stories about
The story of Tales from the Trail, it is really a wonderful honor and a privilege to present for your pleasure, Nicholas Badmaine and John Beckham.
We've got to get more money.
Should we go alphabetically or the hometown guy?
You go.
BA, right?
The husband goes first.
Well, I have to tell you, it really is a great thrill and a great honor for me to not only be here at the Rocky Mountain Book Fair.
It's my first trip ever to Denver.
I did come through once on the way to Colorado Springs.
And as a person who really is committed and dedicated to book culture, book people, book places, anything pertaining to and involving books,
from every aspect of it.
I've always felt that one of the great book cities I really had not been to is Denver.
So when this discussion started generating with Richard, he didn't really accost me in the stand, but it was close I got to say.
I'm teasing.
It was very nice to chat with him, but I was kind of selling books.
You know what that's like when you're involved in a transaction?

comes up, and first of all, you're nervous because somebody recognizes you, you know, and I think, my goodness, I have my hat on with my name on the back of it, but anyway, it was a delight to chat with Richard, and he was proposing this thing up in New Hampshire, and I said, yeah, really, do you think John wants to come up to the, I mean, New Hampshire is wonderful, and I'm a lifelong New England guy.

But I said, on the whole, I'm really much rather go out to Denver and visit this great book city and to come to this fair and to really, for me it's kind of like paying homage to a person I have the greatest respect and admiration for, and that is John Dunning.
And now I'm not teething.
Here we are on this same program, Tales of the Trail, and if I am
The Boswell of the book collecting world, which I, it's not bad, I haven't been called that yet, but I'll call it myself.
If I may digress, my wife, but I've mentioned this at the Colorado State yet, and I forget how there's some, how do they introduce me to something of the book world?
The teen, yeah, the teen.
I said, that's a new one, the dean of the book world.
My wife and I went to Chattanooga, Tennessee once, and the local paper said, the king of the bibliophiles.
I said, wow.
And Connie was with me, and she said, he's impossible enough to live with now.
Now he's really going to be insufferable.
And I've also been described as the Johnny Appleseed.
That's kind of fun, because Johnny Appleseed was a New Englander, and he traveled the country, and he sowed the seeds of apples, I guess apples.
I like to think that I go around and just instilling this, if I can share my passion and my enthusiasm for books and for book people, that I'm doing something productive.
But again, really what I am is a reporter.
I am a storyteller first, but a reporter second.
And what I determined early on is that I could never be a great collector.
I could be a great collector if I had vast sums of money and if I were able to purchase the books that I would really like to have, but I knew that would never happen.
but something I could do as a reporter and as a chronicle is collect collectors, and I've been pretty good at that.

And I think those of you who are familiar with Gentle Madness, really one of the purposes of that book was to go out not only and to write about many of the great collectors through history, which is part one, but part two of that book, I thought I could do something which had never, in my view, been done before.
It was to bring my

modest skills of an investigative reporter, a good interviewer, a person who likes to go out and listen and see things and feel things and touch things and to go out and really write about many of the great collectors of today.

And I thought it would be worthwhile not only to identify these people but to try and box the compass as it were, to do it not only geographically but in terms of those who afford to buy it, all levels of activity, and to write a bunch of stories.
It really is storytelling.
It don't mean a thing if it ain't got that swing, is the way I look at it.
If there's not a good story attached to whatever it is I'm trying to describe, then I will find an instance where there is a good story.
But if I'm the Boswell to complete that thought, I do tend to ramble.
This is Homer over here.
I'm the reporter.
And this is the poet.
So it really is, for me, a great, and I told you I was going to use that line, too, and you said, you better not, I'm out of here.
Out of here, you have to forgive me for the accent.
So it really will be a lot of fun to talk a little bit about some tales of, I guess, is it on the trail or from the trail, a book collecting more of people that I've
been able to meet and write about, and I really have covered every aspect, I mean, from one extreme to the other.
Steven Blumberg, those of you who may be familiar with Chapter 13 of Gentle Madness, called the Blumberg Collection, a rather ironic title.
This is the individual who, over a 20-year period, collected 25,000 books, 20-year period.
Conservatively, the value is conservatively estimated at $20 million.
The one question was provenance.
329 libraries in 45 states, two Canadian provinces in the District of Columbia, fully 95% of which were never known to be missing until the day he was arrested in 1990.
Ken Sanders is here in the back of the room, the ADAA security man.
He'll tell you this is probably the most knowledgeable man in the United States on book theft.
Steven Blumberg, I think we can say, is wise.
the most accomplished book thief of the 20th century.
Here I was embarked on writing a book about the wonderful aspects of bibliomania.
The whole premise of A Gentle Madness was so much of what we value of our history, our culture, our literature would be lost forever if it were for book collectors.
I'm looking around for the vacant looks.
I'm not getting them, thankfully, because we are among kindred spirits.
These are book people here, but I have to say that I was a reporter and a journalist and a
book editor, people would say to me, what are you working on?
And I would say, I'm working on a book about book collectors, and I would get this blank book.
And I'd start telling them, and then the next book, of course, Patience and Fortitude, which is a library, and that really got their attention.
And I would tell them, this is very interesting, there's a chapter in there about off-site storage.
Well, that really, that really is brilliant.
I swear I was introduced once at a program as the author of A Gentle Madness and Pride and Prejudice.
And I had to say, look, this is not a lost Jane Austen novel.
Patience and Fortitude are the names of the lions that stand guide in front of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue in New York, so named during the years of the Great Depression.
Now, this is the world expert, the world authority on radio.

Mayor LaGuardia used to give these Sunday night broadcasts during the years of the Great Depression, and he would unfailingly conclude his remarks by saying words to the effect, what we need to see us through the great ordeal that lay ahead are to exercise the twin virtues of patience and fortitude.
And prior to that, the lines of Tennessee Pink Marble, which

stand guard outside the public library, named, I think, Lennox and Aster, after James Lennox and John Jacob Aster, who were patrons, early patrons of the library, the names thereafter of Patience and Fortitude.
What a great image and metaphor to choose.
Here we are, these declining years of the 20th century, and
And the whole mission, the future of the library is being debated.

I don't think there's any question that libraries will continue into process, but the role and the function of the printed book, the future of the printed book, I thought this image of Lyon's standing guide at the gates of knowledge worked, although occasionally it is confused what in the world is patience and poetry that has to do with book culture.
But that's where that title comes from.
It's been wonderful, I have to say, traveling the country, going to the trial of Steven Blumberg.
This book was supposed to be about people who preserved culture, preserved literature, preserved history.
I find myself in the middle of Iowa for two weeks in one of the coldest winters on record, attending this trial, where the man's defense, by the way, was not guilty by reason of insanity.
Now, if you have a book titled A Gentle Madness,
And this is the only case, I think, in the history of American jurisprudence where what amounts to a case of criminal bibliomania where the defense is going to be insanity.
I did it because I was crazy.
That is a very appealing concept for me, I have to say, and prompted me to take what was supposed to be an 18-month project and it became an eight-year project, a book that
And it's the first contract that I had with Random House that was supposed to be, the book was supposed to be in about 1990, 1991.
It was supposed to be 95,000 words and the final product eight years later with another publisher, Random House Got Tired of Waiting, was $250 for it.
And I'm going to let John talk a little bit now and if you'd like to hear a little bit more of some of the stories from the trail, I'd be more than happy to pick up on it.
Thank you.
Yes, sir.
This is probably a good deal earthier than your part of the program because I think when we talk about, I've got a couple of Gentle Madness stories, but I came to this in a whole different way.
I was a writer a long time ago.
I had written five books, none of which really made any kind of a splash.
most of which you didn't earn out, as they say in the book trade.
That means that you get an advance and you don't make enough to pay your advance back.
And around 1980, I hit the mother of all dry streaks where I couldn't sell anything.
And my wife and I would walk around the neighborhood and talk about what's going to happen when I click again.
She has amazing optimism.
But there comes a time when you have the weight of rejection.
Now I know what word always felt like when they pile the weight on.
And I came to a point where I said, you know, as much as I love the idea of authorship and authorhood and writing books,
Maybe it's time we did something else.
It's been a long time since I've worked for any kind of living.
So she had been in the foreign service, and she had a little nest egg from that.
And when you live with a bookman or a writer, your money is never safe.
And I generously offered to
take her money and open a bookstore for her.
You remember that Isaac Denison line, I had a farm in Africa, I had a bookstore on East Colt.
What a life, we were there, we were there 10 years, and from the first day, it was like magic.
There's a scene in my book, Book to Die,
where they're building the bookstore, and they're building the shelves.
And book scouts would come in off the street with bags of books.
I didn't make this up.
Book scouts would come in, and they would say, are you buying books?
And I had books all over the floor.
And I said, sure.
And Steve Wilson was a guy down the street, a guy with a long, pointy beard, old ex-hippie.
And he would come up, and he was a carpenter.
He would help me build the shelves.
And Steve would say, don't buy that.
It's a dog.
And don't ever buy a book by a female writer with three names.
And don't buy a book that's, don't ever buy a book written by Jane Fonda or anybody.
who has had a best seller attached to their name because there's 8 million copies in The Naked City and you'll die with it.
On the other hand, if you have a book about the history of teeth in North Denver written by a dentist, North Denver was fairly colorful.
And sometimes there wasn't anything left but teeth.
And so he said, buy that.
That's a $60 book.
And I would say, how do you know that?
And he said, just buy it.
And I would buy it.
And I would say, well, what am I going to sell it for?
He said, $60.
And I said, well, I'll die with this book.
And he said, if you price it any lower than $60, I'll buy it.
And I said, well, I don't want to have that.
So price it at $60, and somebody would come in and buy it.
And Nick was talking about the pet names we collect.
I wasn't thinking of those great philosophers.
I was thinking more of Moe, Larry, and Shemp, and I was Larry.
He was the one who died.
I don't know what Steve and Michael were.
Michael was a guy up the street as well, but they were my mentors.
I started out knowing diddly about books.
I still don't know a lot.
I found out that nobody knows all of it, and you can't
You can be a specialist.
You can be introduced as an expert.
I'm always very queasy when they say that.
So I drove my way along on East Colfax.
Didn't write a word.
I was in danger of never writing again.
Or the world was in danger of never seeing it.
But you know, no matter how discouraged you get, there's something about a writer who isn't writing
And eventually, I wrote again and again.
And I was really rusty when I started this book to die.
And it was based on my stuff on East Colfax.
Books to Book Scouts were real.
People who came in stores were real enough.
I hate to tell you how real some of them were.
And I sent it off to New York to my agent.
And she started sending it around, and nobody wanted it, it seemed.
It went and went and went, and a year passed.
And I looked at my wife one day, and the police were sitting in there on Saturday, and I had just gone to the post office and gotten my latest rejection on it.
And I turned to her and I said, I don't think I want to do this anymore.
I'm going to write to my agent and withdraw the book, and I'm going to be a happy book
seller from now on.
And that gentleman sitting right over there, he and I used to share an office.
The guy in the yellow shirt, Mr. Warwick Downing Esquire, we used to share an office where we were both aging, he was more aging than I was, aspiring to keep it going, writers.
And I went in that day to the office, and I sat down and I said,
I've had it.
I'm sick of this stuff.
He said, well, what does that mean?
And I said, I'm going to call the book back and I'm going to burn it.
And he doesn't remember this.
His memory is much faultier than mine.
But he stood up there on his hind legs and he says, if you can even think of doing that, you're going to have to whip me.
He's a wiry guy, smaller than I am.
But he's sneaky.
And I decided I didn't want to try that, so I sent it out one more time, and my agent wrote back and said, at last I get to make money.
I don't care at this point.
I said, I don't care.
She said, you're not going to get much money, so don't.
And I said, I don't care how much money.
She said, Skridner wants to buy it.
And I said, Skridner?
House of Hemingway.
Wolf, Fitzgerald, me.
And I'm sitting there in my bookstore, and we've got about a $35 day going.
There's a lot of those.
Real booksellers like Ken Sanders back there don't know what it's like to have a day like that.
There's nothing but excitement in that store.
But we had a couple of customers who actually just made my life.
I would start out in the morning, and I would cruise Capitol Hill in my car, and I would just suck these books up like a vacuum.
You can't do this anymore.
People don't put them out.
I know, I get some of the blame for that, but, you know, maybe it's true, maybe it isn't.
I would go along and they would throw out the entire Shelby Foote trilogy on the Civil War for $5.
And I'd buy it and come back.
And we had a couple of
a couple of customers, Bob and Harvey Platts, who were usually there on Saturday, and when I would unload the truck, we would sell books on the street before I even got them in the store.
What do you want for this?
I don't know.
I think that set's worth about $60.
Why can't you do a little better?
Well, you know, I got $5.
Okay, right out of check.
And when I sold Bookman's Way,
And then when I saw 2 o'clock Eastern wartime, I had, for the first time, a little bit of money.
And we went to New York, and we went to the New York Book Fair.
I know Ken knows what a danger that is to go into the New York Book Fair thinking you have some money in your pocket.
And I told Helen, I said, I want to find out what it's like to buy a good book and actually pay for it.
And I bought a beautiful copy of The Grapes of Wrath, a bookseller we know.
A great guy came up to me and said, I got $7,500 on this.
You can see, look at it.
It's beautiful.
I'll let you have it for five because it's you.
And I wrote up a check and I handed it to him.
And then I bought

a copy of The Long Valley, and then I bought a copy of Mice and Men, and I walked out of there with a $10,000 tariff, and we got back to our hotel in New York, and I looked at her, and I said, what the hell did I just do?
Is this the general madness or what?
That's it.
I don't do too much of that anymore.
But it has been a trip.
It has been a lot of fun trekking through the book world.
And are we going to
keep this up, or are we going to ask questions, answer questions, or are we going to try to answer questions?
Richard, do you want us to answer questions, or do you want us to talk more?
Talk more.
Talk more.
Talk more what?
Talk more.
You should talk more.
Talk more.
What?
Well, I'll finish this story, and then you can have at it.
I'm on deck.
I got back to Denby, and

All that story about my book scout, he used to come to the store, and the description of, I shouldn't say this too loud, I suppose there's still some action that could be taken about this, but he would come into the store, and he would, he was so difficult, he started out as a pussycat.
He just, I had a reference section, and I said, it's open to anybody.
You want to look my books up?
Fine.
When I come in, we'll talk about it.
He was always desperate.
These guys always lived from hand to mouth, you know.
And I would come in and he would say, I think this is a $50 book, which means I would pay him $20 for it if I was going to sell it for $50.
And I'd look at it and I'd say, is this what you found it for?
I used to have these reference books.
These were the great days before the Internet.
The great days when nobody knew what anything was worth.
And he just made it up.
And some guys made it up better than others, and they were the ones that got rich.
And so then they would get in these books called Bookman's Price Index, which I subscribe to.
And we would look them up in there and find out that, hey, this is a $600 book.
Well, if you can sell it, it's a $600 book.
And he would say, I think this is a $100 book.
And I would say, well, you know, there's four others in there that I can get for $20.
And we would argue back.
It became more and more difficult.
And one day I took my hand and I slammed it down on the counter and I said,
I swear to God, I'm going to write a book about the book trade, and I'm going to put you in it, and I'm going to kill you in the first line.
It's just a coincidence that Bobby the Book Scout was killed at midnight.
And he had cats, and he had them.
I went over to his house one time, and we had the string of drop cord.
He didn't have any electricity.
From the next apartment, it was building darkness.
And he had a light bulb and a drop cord.
And I had to look at his books while cats trek through the place, kind of looking at the books.
And I said, are these cats allowed to have their way in here with these books?
And he said, no, no, they are well trained.
And he put on and picked up the book and bummed it.
He was a piece of work.
And we had some fun.
And then I got out of it.
I still miss parts of it.
I realized that I miss what isn't anymore.

The internet came in, and it spawned a whole raft of people who are knowledgeable, but a whole raft of people who, as my friend Jane Wood would say, can't find their butt with both hands and our little telescope.
Some of them are pathetic.
Anyway, it's a different business today than it was one.
I really sound a hundred years old, you know.
And it's only been ten years ago that all this has happened.
Please, start something before I speak again.
Okay, well, it's been ten years for me, too.

Gentle Madness was published in 1995, and I mentioned how it had been under contract to Random House, and they either tired of waiting for it or whatever, but they one day just unceremoniously said, when I'm publishing this book,
And it was amazing how difficult it was, how almost impossible it was, to find a publisher in New York that would want to publish a book about book collectors.
I said, well, you know, they said, who'd read it?
And I said, you know, book collectors, maybe, to start with.
That might work.
And then, of course, I did have this huge book that was 250.
It is.
I mean, it's a four-pound book.
I've never seen anyone read it on an airplane.
I've seen your book, I have to say, people reading any number of John Denny's books.
airplanes.
Not only are they wonderful reads, they're compact.
They don't weigh five pounds, six pounds.
But the day will come when I will see someone carrying a Gentle Madness on an airplane and I'll embrace that person and take a dress and send out a copy of the next book.
Happily, thankfully, a fellow who used to review books for me by the name of Alan Peacock, a young student at Harvard and I was still a book review editor in Worcester, Massachusetts.
At that time was now a senior editor at Henry Holt of New York and heard that Nick was out there desperately trying to find someone who would publish his book.
And Alan was on a roll at that time.
He had had a couple of Pulitzer Prize winners.
He was really the hot shot at Holt.
He said, all right, send us.
He called my agent.
He said, send Nick's book over.
And I'll never forget this day.
I tear up when I think about it.
He'd had it for the longest time.
He was a notorious, really slow reader.
And then one Thanksgiving, it was 1994, 1993, he called the day before Thanksgiving, this is Alan Peacock.
I want you and your family to have a wonderful Thanksgiving tomorrow.
I'm buying your book.
And I well up when I even think about it.
It was really a fabulous day because we had been wandering the wilderness, I think, for a long time.
nine months, 13 months, whatever it was, who in the world is going to publish this book?
He said, there's just one question I have to ask.
And I said, what's that?
He said, what's wrong with it?
You know, because it had been with Random House and they'd sent it back.
Random House was about to publish it.
It had already been listed in the catalog.
But I was an orphan.
Have you ever been an orphan, John, where you had an editor who acquired you and left and went someplace else, and now you don't have anyone being your champion.
So I actually, by the time my second book was published, I had had nine different editors.
Three editors along that.
It's just amazing.
But anyway, Alan published Gentleman.
One of the reasons it's a scarce book today is that they didn't have that much confidence that it would sell.
So the first printing was 5,800 copies, which thankfully sold out within a few days.
We had three printings within the first month of publication in 1995.
It was a pretty interesting run.
But I do have to say we talk about the Internet and how it has changed the book world.

For me, as a collector, certainly it's changed things, but as a journalist, as a writer, and as a chronicler of this book world, it hasn't changed a thing, except that I can now do searches and using LexisNexis or whatever.
But as a person who really wants to go out and get book stories, I still feel that I have to go out and meet the people I'm going to write about.
I have to go out and handle the goods, see the collections.
It's still very much a tactile exercise for me.
That's the only way I know how to write stories.
There's one story I do like to tell.
We talk about a tale from the trail.
I like to tell it.
It's about a collector by the name of William Scheide, who I would suggest is probably the greatest living book collector in the world.
I write about him in Gentle Madness.
He's still quite alive.
He's in his nineties.
He's a third generation collector.
His library is so extraordinary, it is on the campus of Princeton University in Firestone Library in a little room all by itself.
He owns the building.
Princeton is very clever.
They figure that however old the books are, however long Mr. Shaggy lives, the books will last longer.
And at some point, maybe, this has not been disclosed, the books will go to Princeton.
But it still very much remains a private collection, but it's in Firestone Library.
I devoted a whole chapter to Bill Scheide and Gentle Madness because I couldn't see who else you could even put with him in this one chapter.
There are chapters where I write about three or four different collectors.
They're fine.
They work in one chapter.
For Scheide, he had to be alone.
I went to see him a couple of times at the library at Princeton, in the Firestone Library.
There's one moment I'll never forget.
He walked over to this old stand-up safe that had been his grandfather's.
He was in his 80s at that point and he was struggling with the door and lifting up and removing this big clamshell box.
I offered to help him with the box and he very gruffly said, you go sit down over there, I'll be right over.
It was a reading table and I said, yes sir, okay.
I went over, I sat down and he came over, he opened up this box and then revealed to me what I knew instantly was his copy of the Gutenberg Bible.
in its original 15th century binding, one of only two in private hands in the world.
As I say, these are books that I could never hope to own, but what he was doing was opening and revealing to me and inviting me to touch where metal type had hidden into paper for the first time.
Now, I record everything, as you can see, everything that I'm allowed to, and I put it certainly on my interviews.
You can go back to this day and listen to that tape
hear all of a sudden this elderly voice saying, are you okay?
And you will hear me say, forgive me, sir, I am a bit lightheaded.
And I will continue by saying, and I said, it isn't often that I am allowed to touch a person's Gutenberg Bible.

Harvard would let you handle his anytime.

Really, we will go anywhere to see a great book.

Mark's Library, the Marziana, just really to see the books of Cardinal Busserian.
He was the Greek bishop who fled at the fall of Constantinople in 1453, and he carried out all these wonderful cortices documenting ancient Greek literature.
He was a humanist, actually, and then he converted to the Catholic Church.
It's amazing.
I'm Greek-American, so I can say it's how they will bear a pledge after 500 years.
I went up to Mount Athos for a chapter in Patience and Borgia just to see these books that have been preserved and saved in these monastic libraries for a thousand years.
And one of the monks said to me, well, where have you been?
I said, oh, I went to see Bassarian's books two months ago in Venice.
He said, the traitor.
He was still the traitor because he had converted from...
It's amazing.

It's the oldest, the earliest known copy of Homer that has come down to it.
Now, of course, it's not the oldest text, but it's the oldest surviving text.
You have some of these marginalia, these annotations in the margins.
There are references to books that themselves don't even exist anymore.

You can just wonder and imagine whose fingers have handled this book.
And that's a kick, traveling.
Of course, Venice is nice.
I mean, my wife said, I'll go to Venice with you and go visit that library.
In February, I traveled to Chicago on a day trip, one day, just to go out and see one book.

their spring flower show and to fix the leaky room and using the excuse that nobody comes to see these books anymore they sold off all of these remarkable books they were saying well most of them will go to collective they'll go to institutional collections they won't be broken up but this very astute librarian at the chicago botanic garden had put out the word among his bookseller friends and he gave them a list of titles if you see any of these books show up cannibalized let me know

Well, it's not a scarce book, but it certainly is a very rare book.
But this particular book,
It's an 18th century illustrated book on plants, on fruit-bearing trees.
It has to be the title, but it's a long German title, and I think it's the Nuremberg Hesperides of the short form.
Only one copy of New England, and yet the Horticultural Society had sold it for $50,000.
It sold at Christie's, and within months,
The cannibalized copy had shown up in England.
All of the plates, 258 plates, were gone and had been colored, by the way, and they're selling on the internet now for $1,500 each.
But I went to Chicago just to see, to pay my respects to this one book.
I mean, you go to see a beautiful book, but in this instance it was to go and to pay my respects to this book.
And for me, my books, by the way, are never done.

I have to say one thing about writing nonfiction books, even though they have already appeared between hardcovers and they've been published, and while you're still working on the next one, it all remains a work in progress for me.
I'm continually interested in the collectors I write about, the booksellers I meet, the librarians.
I want to know how everyone is doing.
I've never finished with them.
So even though I had written about the Horticultural Society, a blender of letters, and that book was out, I still went to Chicago to see the book.
came back, wrote an op-ed piece for the Boston Globe, timed it to appear a week before the Spring Flower Show in Boston.

The rule of thumb in the book trade is if they invite you to their house and ask you to give them what it's worth, you're honor-bound and obligated to give them your best shot, consistent with your rent and your budget and all that stuff.
On the other hand, if they put it out for a price, whether it's in a bookstore or yard sale, and I find it, it's mine.
